jobDescription:
I'm now leading an upstart Data Science team in our Worldwide Learning team at Microsoft.  Our challenge is how to apply data science methods and analytics to truly understand the impact of our learning offerings for Microsoft employees, our customers, and our partners.  Thus far, here are some examples of what we've done.
- Employee skilling - we've built ways to use existing internal data sets to really measure the impact of our learning offerings on MS employees.  This has allowed us to understand both behaviorally where learners are demonstrating skills as well as ROI and business impact for key programs.
-  Manager/Coaching - we built a model leveraging calendar data to reflect manger "intensity" relative to time between a manager and their directs to see how our Coaching training created space and autonomy for our employees.
-  Certification planning - we've built a data-driven way to use in-market skills and job data to better understand the need and projections in considering new learning and certifications.
-  Feedback 360 - we've designed a way to integrate all of the different messages we get from our learners into an integrated an usable solution.  We'll be building this in the upcoming year and layering natural language on top of it to really reason across this disparate data.
-  Certification Journey analysis - we've built a model to represent the complete certification journey of any MS certified learner in the past 12 years.  This allows us to build correct paths for learners for new certifications as well as better author marketing and outreach content to get learners to the right destination.
-  Linkedin Analytics - we've partnered closely with our peer teams at LinkedIn to more formally exchange data to use in-market skills as the way to measure our learning business.
